title: Understanding Hypertension
content: Hypertension, commonly known as high blood pressure, occurs when the force of blood against artery walls is consistently too high. It is a major risk factor for heart disease and stroke.

title: What is Hypertension?
content: Blood pressure is measured in millimeters of mercury (mmHg) and recorded as two numbers: systolic and diastolic. Hypertension is defined as having a systolic reading of 130 mmHg or higher, or a diastolic reading of 80 mmHg or higher.

title: Types of Hypertension
content: There are two main types: primary (essential) hypertension, which develops gradually over years, and secondary hypertension, caused by underlying health conditions such as kidney disease or hormonal disorders.

title: Causes and Risk Factors
content: Hypertension can result from a variety of causes, including genetic predisposition, lifestyle factors like poor diet, and medical conditions.

title: Lifestyle Factors
content: Poor diet, excessive salt intake, lack of physical activity, and obesity contribute significantly to the development of hypertension.

title: Genetic and Medical Causes
content: Hypertension often runs in families, suggesting a genetic link. It can also be caused by medical conditions such as sleep apnea, chronic kidney disease, and adrenal gland tumors.

title: Complications of Hypertension
content: Uncontrolled hypertension can lead to serious health problems, including heart attack, stroke, kidney damage, and vision loss.

title: Cardiovascular Complications
content: High blood pressure increases the workload on the heart, leading to conditions like heart failure, coronary artery disease, and arrhythmias.

title: Organ Damage
content: Prolonged hypertension can damage organs such as the kidneys, eyes, and brain. For example, hypertensive nephropathy can lead to kidney failure.

title: Understanding Diabetes
content: Diabetes is a chronic condition characterized by high levels of sugar (glucose) in the blood. It occurs when the body cannot produce enough insulin or cannot effectively use the insulin it produces.

title: What is Diabetes?
content: Diabetes affects the bodyâ€™s ability to regulate blood glucose. Insulin, a hormone produced by the pancreas, plays a key role in moving glucose from the bloodstream into cells for energy.

title: Types of Diabetes
content: There are three main types of diabetes: Type 1 diabetes, an autoimmune condition; Type 2 diabetes, often linked to lifestyle factors; and gestational diabetes, which occurs during pregnancy.

title: Causes and Risk Factors
content: Diabetes can be caused by genetic factors, autoimmune reactions, and lifestyle-related issues such as poor diet, lack of exercise, and obesity.

title: Lifestyle Factors
content: Dietary habits high in sugar and refined carbs, combined with sedentary lifestyles, significantly contribute to the development of Type 2 diabetes.

title: Genetic and Autoimmune Causes
content: Type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune disorder where the immune system attacks insulin-producing cells. Family history can also increase the risk of diabetes.

title: Complications of Diabetes
content: If left uncontrolled, diabetes can lead to severe complications, including cardiovascular disease, kidney failure, nerve damage, and vision loss.

title: Cardiovascular Complications
content: Diabetes increases the risk of heart attack, stroke, and atherosclerosis due to elevated blood sugar damaging blood vessels.

title: Neuropathy and Organ Damage
content: High blood sugar can damage nerves (diabetic neuropathy) and organs, particularly the kidneys (diabetic nephropathy) and eyes (diabetic retinopathy).

title: Understanding Lung Cancer
content: Lung cancer is a type of cancer that begins in the lungs. It is one of the leading causes of cancer-related deaths worldwide and is strongly associated with smoking, though it can also affect non-smokers.

title: What is Lung Cancer?
content: Lung cancer occurs when abnormal cells in the lung grow uncontrollably, forming tumors that interfere with normal lung function.

title: Types of Lung Cancer
content: The two main types of lung cancer are non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), which accounts for about 85% of cases, and small cell lung cancer (SCLC), which is more aggressive but less common.

title: Causes and Risk Factors
content: Lung cancer is primarily caused by long-term exposure to carcinogens, such as those found in cigarette smoke, as well as environmental and genetic factors.

title: Smoking and Carcinogens
content: Smoking is the leading cause of lung cancer. Tobacco contains carcinogens that damage lung cells, leading to mutations and cancer over time.

title: Environmental and Genetic Factors
content: Exposure to radon gas, air pollution, and asbestos can increase lung cancer risk. Family history of lung cancer may also play a role.

title: Symptoms of Lung Cancer
content: Symptoms of lung cancer often appear in the later stages and may include a persistent cough, chest pain, and difficulty breathing.

title: Early Symptoms
content: Early symptoms include a chronic cough, coughing up blood, and unexplained weight loss. These symptoms are often mistaken for less serious conditions.

title: Advanced Symptoms
content: Advanced symptoms may include severe chest pain, hoarseness, and swelling of the face or neck due to tumor pressure on nearby structures.

title: Diagnosis and Treatment
content: Diagnosis of lung cancer involves imaging and biopsy. Treatment options include surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, and targeted therapies, depending on the stage and type of cancer.

title: Diagnostic Methods
content: Methods include chest X-rays, CT scans, and biopsy. PET scans and molecular testing help determine the stage and treatment options.

title: Treatment Approaches
content: Treatment depends on cancer type and stage. Surgery is common for early-stage cancer, while advanced stages may require a combination of therapies.

title: Prevention and Prognosis
content: Quitting smoking, avoiding secondhand smoke, and reducing exposure to environmental risks like radon can lower lung cancer risk. Prognosis varies based on stage and treatment response.

title: Prevention Strategies
content: Avoiding smoking, regular screenings for high-risk individuals, and maintaining a healthy lifestyle can significantly reduce lung cancer risk.

title: Outlook and Survival Rates
content: Survival rates depend on early detection. The 5-year survival rate is significantly higher for localized cancer than for advanced stages.

title: Understanding Influenza
content: Influenza, commonly known as the flu, is a contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses. It can range from mild to severe and can lead to complications, especially in high-risk groups.

title: What is Influenza?
content: Influenza is a viral infection that affects the respiratory system, including the nose, throat, and lungs. It spreads easily through respiratory droplets from coughs, sneezes, or talking.

title: Types of Influenza Viruses
content: There are four main types of influenza viruses: A, B, C, and D. Influenza A and B are responsible for the seasonal flu outbreaks that occur each year.

title: Causes and Risk Factors
content: Influenza is caused by infection with influenza viruses, which mutate frequently. Risk factors include age, certain medical conditions, and weakened immune systems.

title: Transmission of Influenza
content: The flu spreads through respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or talks. It can also spread by touching contaminated surfaces and then touching the face.

title: High-Risk Groups
content: The elderly, young children, pregnant women, and individuals with chronic medical conditions or weakened immune systems are at higher risk of severe flu complications.

title: Symptoms of Influenza
content: Common symptoms include fever, cough, sore throat, muscle aches, fatigue, and chills. In severe cases, influenza can cause pneumonia and other complications.

title: Common Symptoms
content: Symptoms often include a sudden onset of fever, dry cough, sore throat, nasal congestion, and body aches. These symptoms typically last about a week.

title: Severe Symptoms and Complications
content: Severe cases may lead to difficulty breathing, persistent chest pain, or confusion. Complications include pneumonia, bronchitis, and exacerbation of chronic conditions.

title: Diagnosis and Treatment
content: Influenza is diagnosed based on symptoms and can be confirmed with rapid diagnostic tests. Treatment includes rest, hydration, and antiviral medications for severe cases.

title: Diagnostic Methods
content: Doctors often diagnose flu based on clinical symptoms during flu season. Rapid influenza diagnostic tests (RIDTs) or PCR tests can confirm the diagnosis.

title: Treatment Approaches
content: Mild cases can be managed with rest, fluids, and over-the-counter medications. Antiviral drugs like oseltamivir (Tamiflu) may be prescribed for severe cases.

title: Prevention and Vaccination
content: Annual flu vaccination is the most effective way to prevent influenza. Good hygiene practices, like handwashing, can also reduce the risk of infection.

title: Influenza Vaccination
content: The flu vaccine is updated annually to target the most common strains of the virus. It is recommended for everyone over 6 months of age.

title: Hygiene and Other Prevention Strategies
content: Frequent handwashing, covering your mouth when coughing or sneezing, and avoiding close contact with sick individuals can help prevent flu transmission.

title: Understanding Asthma
content: Asthma is a chronic respiratory condition that causes inflammation and narrowing of the airways, making breathing difficult. It affects people of all ages and can range from mild to severe.

title: What is Asthma?
content: Asthma is characterized by episodes of wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and coughing. These symptoms occur due to inflammation and sensitivity of the airways to certain triggers.

title: Types of Asthma
content: There are several types of asthma, including allergic asthma triggered by allergens, exercise-induced asthma, and occupational asthma caused by workplace irritants.

title: Causes and Triggers
content: Asthma can be triggered by a combination of genetic and environmental factors, including allergens, respiratory infections, and air pollution.

title: Common Triggers
content: Common asthma triggers include pollen, dust mites, mold, pet dander, smoke, cold air, and strong odors. Physical exertion and stress can also provoke symptoms.

title: Genetic Factors
content: Asthma often runs in families, indicating a genetic predisposition. However, not everyone with a family history of asthma will develop the condition.

title: Managing and Treating Asthma
content: Asthma management involves avoiding triggers, using prescribed medications, and monitoring symptoms. With proper care, most people can lead normal, active lives.

title: Medications
content: Asthma medications include long-term control drugs like inhaled corticosteroids and quick-relief inhalers such as bronchodilators to ease acute symptoms.

title: Lifestyle Adjustments
content: Maintaining a healthy lifestyle, avoiding triggers, and using an asthma action plan can help reduce the frequency and severity of symptoms.
